I think with the advent of ebooks, it's a great thing.  I personally like 
being able to read without having to take a large book with me if I'm 
traveling, but I still have a sizable book collection at home for when I 
can relax.  What parents really need to do is focus on getting their kids 
to read at all.  I grew up in the 90s, but my parents read to me, and 
encouraged me to read so much that it was one of my favorite past-times.

still reading novels and going to the library every other day.  It's ALL 
about fostering love of reading.  Some parents do it better than others.

comments.text:
+Christian playsgames The technology I mentioned? Not really. Before 
electricity and running water, we had wells, and we just didn't stay up 
much when it was dark (or if we had to see in the dark, we used a candle). 
The species survived just fine. But these things made our lives much 
easier, allowed more people access to water and light, and generally 
changed the way humanity did things. Telephones did that as well, as did 
the Internet, as did smartphones. It's making our lives easier, connecting 
us in new ways, and changing the way that we live our lives, but none of it 
is absolutely necessary for our survival. It's just technology!
comments.author: Jacob Kieval

comments.text: But it's all for our survival

comments.text:
+TheTubePortal You shouldn't condemn it, and you shouldn't allow free use 
of it either. Those are opposite ends of the scale, and they both are 
equally bad. You should teach, control and limit until your child will be 
able to do it by himself, and more importantly, when he will understand why 
he should do it.
comments.author: Slithereenn

comments.text:
+TheTubePortal
I don't condemn the idea of children learning and using technology, but 
rather use in excess. There is no real need for that child to have a phone. 
Children, especially the younger ones, should be spending time with family 
that is with them, rather than playing Angry Birds or texting someone 
elsewhere. Technology is good, very good in fact. Yet as with all things, 
too much of a good thing is bad. It is much better for them to learn proper 
communication before being introduced fully to the quick methods of today. 
I will teach everything to my kid about technology--the good and the 
bad--when they're young. They'll learn how to use the internet properly, 
stupid pranks for fun, phone things, but within moderation. Yet my kid 
doesn't need a 400 dollar piece of easily broken technology in which the 
only contact they need at that age is his parents.
In a quick sum up of everything about phones though, regardless of the age, 
here is a quick quote from Einstein that holds true today (paraphrased): 
The day technology surpasses our human interaction, we will have a 
generation of idiots. And I'm sorry, but there are a lot of idiots out 
there in our generation txting and tweeting and facebooking all day on 
phones all day. I don't mean they're idiots because they're on the phone, 
but they're idiots and they happen to be constantly on the phone.
comments.author: WrittenInShadow

comments.text:
+WrittenInShadow
I'm going to be 22 in a month. I just think that the whole idea of 
condemning technology or the use of technology by the young is silly. It's 
the same thing that old people say every generation. I'd don't understand 
why people aren't more open minded now than in the past. The grandparents 
of the early 1900s grew up with very little tech so they couldn't 
understand why kids liked or needed the things they had because the 
grandparents didn't have them. But now that tech is everywhere and the pace 
of change is faster I figured our generation was more open to it, and that 
we wouldn't turn out like our grandparents. Oh well.
comments.author: TheTubePortal

comments.text:
+TheTubePortal
Yes, technology is a great thing, yet a tablet will never have the feeling 
of a hard book in your hands. The part about the newspapers, well, they're 
going out because no one reads them anyway, since everything is much more 
easily available--which has nothing to do with kids having iphones that 
young. I'm 22, yet I will never think of letting my kid have a phone until 
they're old enough to a, be responsible for it, and b, have an actual need, 
such as having a car which can break down or a job which if he doesn't have 
a car will he might have a bicycle and therefore call when it's raining. 
Well, it would be the latter, actually, because in order to teach the value 
of money and how to save, I would have him pay for half the car from the 
money from his job.
And lastly, are you bitter that your grandmother wouldn't buy you a TV for 
you to fool around watching as a kid? I must insist that a kid doesn't need 
a TV in his room at twelve years old.
comments.author: WrittenInShadow

unnecessary, specifically cellphones or iphones. The same arguments made 
about the iphone are IDENTICAL to the arguments made by previous

top_comment.text:
For the guy with relatives in Chicago - in that region, even local calls 
were metered by the minute - just at much lower rates than long distance.

My dad taught us to never make long distance calls unless absolutely 
necessary, and to keep them as short as possible - mostly because he 
learned the habit at a time when the phone company had a special rate for 
long distance calls - $3 for 3 minutes anywhere in the USA. At this time, 
$3 was about a day's wages for most workers.

But even so he claims he preferred the phone system he had as a kid. He 
would pick up the phone to call his mother, and if he didn't know where she 
was the operator did, and would connect the call accordingly. (He grew up 
in a small town.) No dialing was necessary.﻿

comments.text:
From what I have seen in the video footage, most of these kids have phone 
numbers pre-programmed into their cell phones.  They almost never have to 
used a phone dial at all.  I do not know if these I-Phones have a "queuing" 
feature, allowing an incoming call to be put into a "waiting" mode, until 
the call is answered by the recipient of the call.  If that is the case, it 
would not be surprising that these kids would never experience a busy 
signal.  This would be more likely in the "high-tech" Silicon Valley of 
California, but for the rest of America, where older phones and phone 
systems are still used, most of us still deal with busy signals, even with 
cell phones and I-Phones.

on tech that it interferes with their daily activities (some-what like me) 
and depend on going to the library instead to look for facts (for school 
and business). Tech can get you hooked.. and make you anti-social.

It is difficult not to play video games knowing that my mom and half of my 
other family members do and ending up to play FB games at social events 
such as Memorial Day. Lol. It's kind of like soda, the first time you take 
a sip, you either fall in love with it or you don't. That's why you 
shouldn't try it at all. I'll admit that I use to spend hours and hours on 
the computer (I still do at times) playing FB games, ROBLOX, GTA games, 
etc. I'm not that bad as I use to be, I can tell a difference in my 
behavior and my attitude. Family is more important.

comments.text:
+Jacob Young
Maybe not cool....but maybe necessary to keep the memories from fading. How 
would they react to Pearl Harbor? To bombing of Dresden images? To 
Holocaust images.  Kids face tragedy all the time and people can learn from 
how kids react...and improve how they treat their traumas.  Never 
forgetting is teaching our children about it.  These are funny bits....but 
there can be something gained by seeing how kids react to things that 
aren't so funny.
comments.author: Michael Collins

comments.text:
To the guy (who's comment was deleted because of profanity) - why not? It's 
an honest look at what kids would see today and a good thing to show why we 
should still remember the event....not let it fade away like it seems to 
have. It was a serious thing to ask. If you are offended by the suggestion, 
it is you who need to take a hike.  Ask a serious question...how kids react 
NOW compared to then and see what reaction they have. Are you that small 
minded to show kids exactly how cruel people can be and further their 
understanding of the world..especially those who did not live through 
this?  Should we have banned all Pearl Harbor TV and movie events?  It has 
validity to study how kids react to events of our past. That is why I posed 
this.  That you took offense and called me a POS shows your total ignorance 
of what kids are and aren't capable of.
comments.author: Michael Collins
